symptoms.name: Maculopapular rash
symptoms.pattern: Present in whole body, including face; may involve palms and soles

symptoms.name: Hepatomegaly
symptoms.severity: Common in early congenital syphilis, but absent in this case
symptoms.pattern: Almost always present in infected infants

symptoms.name: Syphilitic rhinitis
symptoms.severity: Can be serious, bloody, purulent, and infectious
symptoms.pattern: Earliest finding, often seen in the first week of life; absent in this case

symptoms.name: Bone pathologies
symptoms.severity: Can involve multiple bones, usually bilateral and symmetric; osteochondritis can cause pain and pseudoparalysis

symptoms.name: Neurosyphilis
symptoms.severity: Asymptomatic in 40% of patients; acute form presents with symptoms similar to bacterial meningitis (vomiting, feeding difficulties, fontanel bulging, rapid head growth) within the first year; chronic form presents with hydrocephalus, cranial nerve paralysis, growth retardation, optic atrophy, and seizures after the first year
symptoms.pattern: Not assessed in this case due to parental refusal of lumbar puncture

VDRL.mother: Positive (titre unknown at birth; 1/320 positive on first day of baby's life)

lab_values.TPHA: Positive on first day of life
lab_values.Anti-T. pallidum IgG + IgM: Positive (23.83 IU/mL at 48 hours of treatment; decreased to 22.42-13.48 IU/mL at 3 months)
lab_values.Complete blood count: Not specified, but anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia/leukocytosis are common in congenital syphilis

required: Clinical manifestations consistent with early congenital syphilis (e.g., rash, jaundice, hepatomegaly, bone lesions, neurosyphilis)
